title: Going Beyond the Ordinary
subtitle: User Perceptions of Multisensory Elements in VR

nodes.label: Start Here
nodes.title: Introduction
nodes.summary: Location-based VR usage is growing. This study explores 'Hyper-Reality' - adding physical sensations to VR.
nodes.content:
Location-based virtual reality (VR) attractions are gaining popularity. These experiences often go 'beyond the ordinary' by stimulating senses exceeding standard headsets, using vibrating floors, wind, and heaters. This is often called 'Hyper-Reality'. 

This research investigates the impacts of these sensory additions—wind, vibration, free-roam walking, avatars, and virtual hands—on user presence.

nodes.label: Wind
nodes.title: Blowing Wind
nodes.summary: Wind was found to be one of the most impactful elements for presence.
nodes.content:
Participants experienced fans simulating wind at different intensities. 

**Finding:** Blowing wind was rated as one of the most impactful elements for presence, alongside free-roam walking. This supports previous research (e.g., Hülsmann et al., 2014) that wind bolsters the sensation of being there.

nodes.label: Walking
nodes.title: Free-Roam Walking
nodes.summary: Walking freely contributed significantly to the sense of agency and presence.
nodes.content:
The audience walked through a 15-minute experience. 

**Finding:** Free-roam walking was tied with wind as the most impactful element. The ability to move naturally increases the 'Sense of Agency'—the feeling of 'I did this' rather than 'this was done for me'.

nodes.label: Vibration
nodes.title: Floor Vibration
nodes.summary: Vibrating floors simulated ground shaking, comparable to seeing avatars in impact.
nodes.content:
Floor vibration plates were used to simulate the ground shaking for about 30 seconds. 

**Finding:** Contrary to some expectations (the 'Vibrotactile Less Effective Hypothesis'), vibration was fairly impactful, ranking below wind/walking but similar to avatars. Regular VR users rated it slightly higher than occasional users.

nodes.label: Avatars
nodes.title: Audience Avatars
nodes.summary: Seeing other real people as avatars boosted social presence and plausibility.
nodes.content:
Participants could see each other's avatars almost continuously. 

**Finding:** Seeing avatars of real people enhanced the 'Plausibility Illusion'—the feeling that events are actually happening. It ranked similarly to floor vibration in impact.

nodes.label: Hands
nodes.title: Virtual Hands
nodes.summary: Virtual hands had the least perceived impact, possibly due to lack of hand-based tasks.
nodes.content:
Participants saw their own virtual hands via finger trackers. 

**Finding:** Virtual hands were rated as the *least* influential element on presence. 

**Why?** 
1. The experience didn't require hand interactions (unlike stone-moving tasks in other studies).
2. Virtual hands are now common in standard VR, so they may seem less 'novel' or 'special' to users.

nodes.label: Conclusion
nodes.title: Key Takeaways
nodes.summary: To boost presence: Focus on Wind and Walking.
nodes.content:
This study of 726 participants in a real-world setting (Royal Opera House) suggests that to maximize presence in Hyper-Reality:

1. **Prioritize Wind & Free-Roam Walking**: These have the highest perceived impact.
2. **Vibration & Avatars**: Moderate impact.
3. **Visual Fidelity of Hands**: Lower priority unless the task specifically requires manual interaction.

Designers should focus budget and technical effort on environmental haptics and freedom of movement.
